visualization_prompt: Generate a map chart showing geographic points of interest over a base layer using interactive pan/zoom controls and custom marker symbols
visualization_explanation: The dataset contains two-dimensional geospatial coordinates (longitude/latitude) with categorical event labels. Synthetic points were generated using normal distribution (μ=6.5811, σ=0.005 for longitude; μ=61.0870, σ=0.003 for latitude) to create clustered patterns around the primary incident location while maintaining real-world coordinate validity. The base map layer provides geographic context through OpenStreetMap's tiled web service. This visualization employs Tufte's data-ink ratio principles by minimizing decorative elements while maximizing informational density through precise coordinate plotting and Cairo's perceptual transparency by using high-contrast marker symbols with outline borders for clear feature discrimination. The clustered spatial distribution (σ=0.005° ≈ 550m) reflects realistic operational ranges for incident response scenarios, with marker colors using preattentive processing (gold/yellow on blue basemap) for immediate visual salience. Interactive pan/zoom controls maintain Cleveland's hierarchy of graphical interaction while preserving initial map context through the activation button design.
